One other area that could possibly be modified is transmitters 9 Those who have closed
circuit operations and donft intend to go on the air* are not interested in the problems
of transmitters* Those who are on the air are not concerned with Ob problems of ob¬
taining construction permits, proof of performance measurements etc* Only those who
plan to go on the air in the near future have much interest in these problems. There¬
fore it might be better to devote this time to problems of general interest0
Our expectations were more than fulfilled, particularly in the field of kinescope re¬
cording« The wealth of information presented in the sessions on light, lighting, kine¬
scope recorder operation, and film characteristics and processing, provided us with
answers to many of our problemsc For example: knowing nothing about lighting, we took
the word of the production people as God* Some of our sets we*re sure had in excess
300 foot candles of base lights One show that we tried to kinescope had a contrast
ratio far in excess of the recommended 20-1 a The difficulties encountered we attrib¬
uted tofanlty kinescope operations
As far as operation of equipment is concerned, we do not feel that it would contribute
much to the Workshop, It would take considerable time, and few of us would gain much
by pushing cameras, or twiddling beam current controls* Specific procedures such as
setting up a kinescope recorder could better be handled by the NAEB Engineering Serv¬
ice at individual stations—possibly training aids such as tape lectures with slides
could be prepared to assist in developing operating techniques.
Much information was presented in the field of kinescope recording* This undoubtedly
will show in the future in the form of better kinescopes* However, much is left to be
done in this field* For example, the kinescope shown by Jim Johnson of W0I-TV was far
superior to any shown by Mr* DsLand. The new Eastman 737k film coupled with the tech¬
nique of aperature correction seems to make possible film quality in excess of the capa¬
bilities of film pickup systems* For any type of film used in kinescope recording there
are optimum negative and positive process gammas. These are dictated by the maximum
light output and linearity of the kinescope tube, and the linearity and sensitivity
of the films used. At present there are as many standards as there are kinescoping
units, and to send a negative to a lab with the instructions "print for best picture”
leaves much to be desired* To obtain not just acceptable kinescopes, but top quality
ones requires that these optimum characteristics be determined* It remains as a chal¬
lenge to us to arrive at and specify these standards*
Of great value at both of the NAEB Television Engineering Workshops has been the
opportunity to get together on an informal basis with other members of the Work¬
shop, and with technical representatives* At these "bull sessions" many ideas
have been discussed and evaluated. Some of these ideas will be tried and better
kinescopes, better film pickup techniques, or better camera operation may be the
result. It would be of great value to get together more often to further this
exchange of ideas. One proposal is that we organize area workshops mid-way
between the regular workshops. This would have several advantages. By confining
it to smaller areas, for example—Minnesota, Wisconsin, Illinois, and Iowa—
transportation costs could be lessened, the number of people from each station
could be increased, and many ideas would be obtained from seeing other operating
units. These workshops could also be held in areas where no educational insti¬
tutions are, but where items of general interest are, such as the new Vita-Scan
